title: Vulcano
meta_title: Vulcano — Eruption History, Height & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Vulcano is the island that named all volcanoes. A 500 m stratovolcano in Italy's Aeolian Islands with 44 eruptions, active fumaroles, mud baths, and crater hikes.

quick_answer.what: Vulcano is a dormant stratovolcano rising to 500 m (1,640 ft) on the island of the same name in the Aeolian Islands, Italy — the volcano that gave its name to all others.
quick_answer.status: Dormant with active fumaroles — last erupted 1888–1890. The 2021 unrest episode (elevated gas, seismicity) raised the alert level.
quick_answer.famous_for: Being the etymological origin of the word 'volcano' (from the Roman god Vulcan) and defining the 'Vulcanian' eruption type through its 1888–1890 eruption.
quick_answer.danger_level: Moderate — approximately 700 permanent residents plus thousands of summer tourists. The 2021 gas crisis demonstrated ongoing hazard.

hero.name: Vulcano
hero.subtitle: The Volcano That Named Them All

key_facts_box.tectonic_setting: Subduction zone — African Plate beneath Eurasian Plate
key_facts_box.summit_crater: La Fossa cone (391 m), actively fuming
key_facts_box.protected_status: Aeolian Islands UNESCO World Heritage Site (2000)
key_facts_box.monitoring_agency: INGV — Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica e Vulcanologia

overview.content: Vulcano is a dormant stratovolcano rising to 500 m (1,640 ft) on the island of the same name in the Aeolian Islands, a volcanic archipelago in the Tyrrhenian Sea north of Sicily, Italy. It is the volcano that gave its name to all others — the ancient Romans believed the island was the chimney of the forge of Vulcan, the god of fire, and from this myth the word 'volcano' entered the world's languages. Vulcano has erupted 44 times during the Holocene, with its most recent major eruption occurring in 1888–1890, a violent Vulcanian-style explosive event that defined the 'Vulcanian' eruption type still used in volcanological classification today. The volcano is part of the Aeolian Volcanic Arc, generated by the subduction of the African Plate beneath the Eurasian Plate in the central Mediterranean. Vulcano's complex structure spans six stages of construction over the past 136,000 years, including two overlapping calderas and multiple eruptive centers. The island measures approximately 3 × 7 km and is home to around 700 permanent residents, though tourist numbers swell dramatically in summer. La Fossa cone, the most recently active vent located within the Caldera della Fossa, has been the site of most historical eruptions and continues to exhibit vigorous fumarolic activity — particularly at the summit crater rim and on the beach of Porto di Levante, where volcanic gases bubble through shallow waters at the famous 'Fanghi' (volcanic mud baths). In 2021, an increase in volcanic gas emissions, ground temperature, and seismicity prompted Italian authorities to raise the alert level, reminding scientists and residents that Vulcano's silence since 1890 should not be mistaken for extinction. The island is a popular tourist destination within the Aeolian Islands UNESCO World Heritage Site and is easily reached by hydrofoil from Stromboli, Lipari, and mainland Sicily.

geology_and_formation.content: Vulcano is part of the Aeolian Volcanic Arc, a chain of seven volcanic islands in the southern Tyrrhenian Sea produced by the complex subduction of the African Plate beneath the Eurasian Plate. The tectonic setting is unusually complex — the Aeolian arc sits at the junction of multiple microplates and involves both subduction and back-arc extension, producing a diverse range of magma compositions from basaltic to rhyolitic. Vulcano's primary rock types are trachybasalt, tephrite, and basanite — alkaline compositions that reflect the unique mantle source beneath the Aeolian arc. The volcanic complex has been constructed during six stages over the past 136,000 years. Two major caldera collapses shaped the island's structure: the 2.5 km-wide Caldera del Piano on the southeast (formed ~100,000 years ago) and the 4 km-wide Caldera della Fossa on the northwest (formed between 24,000 and 15,000 years ago). Volcanism has migrated northward over time, and the currently active La Fossa cone occupies the 3 km-wide Caldera della Fossa at the island's northwestern end. Vulcanello, a roughly circular lava platform at the island's northern tip, formed as a separate island beginning more than 2,000 years ago and was connected to the main island by volcanic activity around 1550 CE. Vulcanello is capped by three small pyroclastic cones and was intermittently active until the 16th century.

eruption_history_overview.content: Vulcano's 44 confirmed Holocene eruptions span from approximately 6550 BCE to 1890, with both La Fossa cone and Vulcanello serving as active vents at various times. The eruption record reveals a complex pattern of activity involving multiple vents and eruption styles. Vulcanello was particularly active during the Greco-Roman period, with eruptions recorded in 183 BCE (VEI 4 — the largest known Holocene event), 126 BCE, 91 BCE, and intermittently through the early centuries CE. La Fossa cone has been active throughout the Holocene, with notable VEI 3 eruptions in approximately 2650 BCE, 1300 BCE, 526 CE, 925 CE, 1444, 1550, 1626, 1727, 1731, 1771, 1873, 1886, and 1888. The historical period from the 15th century onward is well-documented, with frequent eruptions from La Fossa producing the explosive, block-laden eruption style that would eventually be named 'Vulcanian' after the 1888–1890 event.

subsections.title: The 1888–1890 Eruption — Defining the 'Vulcanian' Eruption Type
subsections.content: The most scientifically significant eruption of Vulcano began on August 3, 1888, and continued with intermittent explosions until March 1890. This VEI 3 eruption from La Fossa cone was characterized by violent, cannon-like explosions that ejected dense clouds of ash, volcanic bombs, and incandescent blocks from the summit crater. The eruption was studied in detail by Italian geologists Giuseppe Mercalli and Orazio Silvestri, whose observations became the basis for defining the 'Vulcanian' eruption type — a classification still used worldwide to describe short, violent explosive eruptions that produce dense, dark ash clouds and ballistic blocks, typically from relatively viscous magma. The eruption caused significant damage on the island, and the population was evacuated during the most intense phases. Breadcrust bombs — volcanic projectiles with cracked, crusty exteriors formed when the hot interior expanded after the cooled outer surface had solidified — are abundantly preserved on the slopes of La Fossa from this eruption and are a distinctive geological feature of the summit area today. The 1888–1890 eruption was the last major eruptive event at Vulcano, and the volcano has been in a state of fumarolic activity (solfataric stage) since then.

subsections.title: The 183 BCE Eruption — Birth of Vulcanello
subsections.content: Around 183 BCE, a submarine eruption off the northern tip of Vulcano created the new island of Vulcanello in a VEI 4 event — the largest known Holocene eruption of the Vulcano complex. This eruption was documented by Roman historians and demonstrated the volcanic system's capacity for vigorous explosive activity from submarine vents. Vulcanello continued to erupt intermittently over the following centuries, with recorded events in 126 BCE, 91 BCE (VEI 3), and possibly as late as the early centuries CE. By approximately 1550 CE, continued volcanic activity and sedimentation had connected Vulcanello to the main island, forming the low peninsula visible today.

subsections.title: 18th Century Activity — La Fossa's Frequent Explosions
subsections.content: The 18th century was a notably active period for La Fossa cone, with VEI 3 eruptions in 1727, 1731, 1771, and a possible VEI 3 in 1786. The 1727 eruption involved activity at both the Forgia Vecchia vent and La Fossa, while the 1771 eruption produced significant pyroclastic material. These eruptions occurred during a period when the island was sparsely populated, primarily used for sulfur mining and agriculture, and were documented by visiting naturalists whose accounts contribute to our understanding of Vulcanian eruption dynamics.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Vulcano has not erupted since 1890 but is far from extinct. The volcano is monitored by INGV (Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica e Vulcanologia), which maintains seismometers, ground deformation sensors, gas monitoring equipment, and thermal cameras on the island. The summit crater of La Fossa exhibits vigorous fumarolic activity, with temperatures at some vents exceeding 300°C. In September 2021, a significant increase in volcanic gas emissions (particularly CO2 and SO2), ground temperatures, and micro-seismicity prompted Italian authorities to raise the alert level from green to yellow, and briefly to orange. Residents and tourists near the crater and at Porto di Levante were affected by elevated gas levels, and access to the summit crater area was restricted. The 2021 unrest episode lasted several months before activity gradually subsided, though elevated gas emissions persisted into 2022. The episode was a stark reminder that Vulcano's 135-year quiet period does not indicate the end of volcanic activity, and that renewed eruptions remain a real possibility.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Vulcano's hazards are amplified by its status as a popular tourist island. Primary hazards include Vulcanian explosive eruptions from La Fossa cone producing ballistic blocks, ash columns, and pyroclastic surges; phreatic (steam-driven) explosions from the shallow hydrothermal system; volcanic gas emissions (CO2, SO2, H2S) that can reach dangerous concentrations in low-lying areas and enclosed spaces; and tsunamis potentially generated by submarine volcanic activity or flank collapse. The island's permanent population of approximately 700 people swells to several thousand during the summer tourist season, when visitors hike to the La Fossa crater rim and bathe in the volcanic mud pools at Porto di Levante. During the 2021 unrest, gas concentrations at Porto di Levante reached levels concerning for human health. A renewed eruption during peak tourist season would present significant evacuation challenges, as the island's port capacity is limited. The Aeolian Islands' vulnerability to volcanic hazards is compounded by the difficulty of marine evacuation during poor weather conditions.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Vulcano is the southernmost of the seven main Aeolian Islands, located approximately 20 km north of Sicily's Capo Milazzo. The elongated island measures roughly 3 × 7 km. Its topography is dominated by two overlapping calderas: the southeastern Caldera del Piano and the northwestern Caldera della Fossa. La Fossa cone, the most prominent landmark, rises to 391 m within the Caldera della Fossa, its barren yellow-white slopes streaked with sulfur deposits and fumarolic vents clearly visible from approaching ferries. The island's highest point (500 m) is on the southern caldera rim. Vulcanello, the low circular peninsula at the northern tip, is connected to the main island by a narrow tombolo. Porto di Levante and Porto di Ponente, on either side of the Vulcanello isthmus, serve as the island's main harbors. The famous volcanic mud baths (Fanghi di Vulcano) are located at Porto di Levante, where geothermally heated waters and sulfurous mud attract tourists. The island's landscape is stark and dramatic — barren fumarolic areas, sulfur-stained rock, and sparse Mediterranean scrub, with more lush vegetation in the sheltered southeastern caldera.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Vulcano's eruptions have been local to regional in their atmospheric effects, as the maximum VEI of 4 (the 183 BCE Vulcanello eruption) is below the threshold for significant global climate impact. The volcano's primary atmospheric significance is its continuous degassing — the fumarolic emissions from La Fossa crater and submarine vents contribute to the regional volcanic gas budget of the Aeolian arc, and the island serves as a natural laboratory for studying volcanic gas chemistry and its effects on local ecosystems and air quality.

cultural_significance.content: Vulcano holds a unique place in world culture as the volcano that named all others. The ancient Greeks called the island 'Hiera' (sacred to Hephaestus, god of the forge), and the Romans named it 'Vulcanus' after their fire god, believing it to be the chimney of Vulcan's forge where he crafted weapons for the gods. From this Roman name, the Italian 'vulcano' entered European languages and became the universal term for all volcanic mountains. The island's sulfur deposits were mined from antiquity through the 19th century — sulfur was a strategic commodity used in gunpowder, medicine, and chemical manufacture. The Stevenson family (including the father of Robert Louis Stevenson) invested in Vulcano's sulfur mines in the mid-19th century. Today, the island's volcanic heritage is its primary cultural and economic asset, drawing tourists to the crater hike, mud baths, and the dramatic Aeolian seascape. The Aeolian Islands were inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2000, with Vulcano recognized for its outstanding examples of volcanic processes and its contribution to the science of volcanology.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Vulcano is one of the most accessible active volcanic islands in the world, reached by hydrofoil or ferry from Milazzo (Sicily) in approximately 1–1.5 hours, or by shorter connections from Lipari (10 minutes) and other Aeolian islands. The island offers several distinctive volcanic experiences. The hike to the summit crater of La Fossa takes approximately 1 hour from Porto di Levante, following a well-maintained trail up the steep, sulfur-encrusted slopes to the crater rim, where visitors can look into the actively fuming crater — one of the most accessible views into an active volcanic vent in Europe. The volcanic mud baths (Fanghi) at Porto di Levante are a famous attraction, where visitors immerse themselves in warm, sulfurous mud believed to have therapeutic properties. Nearby, volcanic gases bubble through the shallow sea at the Acque Calde (hot waters) beach. The island offers accommodation ranging from basic apartments to boutique hotels. Note that during periods of elevated volcanic activity, access to the crater and mud baths may be restricted — this occurred during the 2021 unrest. The summer season (June–September) is peak time, when ferries are frequent and the island is crowded; spring and autumn offer more peaceful visits. Stromboli, famous for its continuous eruptions, is visible from Vulcano and can be visited as a day trip.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Vulcano sits within the Aeolian Volcanic Arc alongside six other volcanic islands. Stromboli, approximately 50 km to the northeast, is famous for its near-continuous Strombolian eruptions and is one of the most active volcanoes in the world. Lipari, the largest Aeolian island, hosts obsidian flows and pumice deposits from eruptions as recent as 729 CE. The other Aeolian islands — Salina, Panarea, Filicudi, and Alicudi — are also volcanic in origin though less recently active. On the Italian mainland and Sicily, Etna (3,357 m, Europe's most active volcano) lies approximately 100 km to the south, and Vesuvius (1,281 m) is approximately 350 km to the north on the Bay of Naples. The submarine volcano Marsili, one of Europe's largest, lies beneath the Tyrrhenian Sea between the Aeolian Islands and the mainland. Italy has 13 Holocene volcanoes, the highest count in Europe.

etymology.content: The name 'Vulcano' derives directly from the Roman god Vulcan (Latin: Vulcanus), the deity of fire, metalworking, and the forge. The Romans believed the island was the location of Vulcan's workshop, where he forged weapons for the gods, and that the volcanic eruptions and flames visible from the summit were the sparks from his anvil. This name passed into Italian as 'vulcano' and subsequently into virtually every European language as the generic term for all volcanically active mountains — making this small Aeolian island the etymological source of one of geology's most fundamental terms.

facts: Vulcano is the etymological source of the word 'volcano' in virtually every European language, derived from the Roman god Vulcan.
The 'Vulcanian' eruption type — a volcanological classification used worldwide — is named after the 1888–1890 eruption of this volcano.
The ancient Romans believed Vulcano was the chimney of Vulcan's forge, where the god crafted weapons for the other deities.
In September 2021, a significant increase in gas emissions and seismicity prompted Italian authorities to raise Vulcano's alert level for the first time in decades.
Vulcano's volcanic complex spans six construction stages over 136,000 years, with two major caldera collapses shaping the island.
Vulcanello, now a peninsula at the island's northern tip, was a separate island created by a submarine eruption around 183 BCE and connected to the main island by ~1550 CE.
The 183 BCE VEI 4 eruption — the creation of Vulcanello — was documented by Roman historians and is the largest known Holocene event.
Summit fumarole temperatures at La Fossa crater exceed 300°C, and the distinctive sulfur-yellow deposits are visible from approaching ferries.
The volcanic mud baths (Fanghi) at Porto di Levante attract thousands of tourists annually who immerse themselves in geothermally heated sulfurous mud.
The Stevenson family (including the father of Robert Louis Stevenson) invested in Vulcano's sulfur mines in the mid-19th century.
Breadcrust bombs from the 1888–1890 eruption — volcanic projectiles with cracked, crusty exteriors — are still abundant on the slopes of La Fossa.
The Aeolian Islands, including Vulcano, were inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2000 for their outstanding examples of volcanic processes.

faqs.question: Is Vulcano still active?
faqs.answer: Vulcano is classified as dormant but not extinct. Its last eruption occurred in 1888–1890, approximately 135 years ago. However, vigorous fumarolic activity continues at La Fossa crater, with fumarole temperatures exceeding 300°C. In 2021, a significant increase in gas emissions, ground temperature, and seismicity prompted authorities to raise the alert level, demonstrating that the volcano's magmatic system remains alive. INGV continuously monitors the volcano. Volcanologists do not rule out renewed eruptions, and the 135-year quiet period is not unprecedented in Vulcano's history.

faqs.question: Why is the volcano called Vulcano?
faqs.answer: The island takes its name from Vulcan (Latin: Vulcanus), the Roman god of fire and the forge. The ancient Romans believed the island was the location of Vulcan's workshop, where he forged weapons for the gods, and that volcanic eruptions were sparks from his anvil. From this Roman name, the Italian 'vulcano' passed into other European languages and became the universal term for all volcanic mountains. Vulcano is therefore the etymological source of one of geology's most fundamental terms — making it unique among the world's volcanoes.

faqs.question: Can you visit Vulcano?
faqs.answer: Vulcano is one of the most accessible active volcanic islands in the world. Hydrofoils and ferries from Milazzo (Sicily) reach the island in 1–1.5 hours, with shorter connections from Lipari (10 minutes). The hike to La Fossa crater takes approximately 1 hour, offering views into the actively fuming crater. The volcanic mud baths at Porto di Levante are a famous attraction. Accommodation ranges from basic apartments to boutique hotels. Access to the crater and mud baths may be restricted during volcanic unrest, as occurred in 2021. Summer is peak season but spring and autumn are more peaceful.

faqs.question: What is a Vulcanian eruption?
faqs.answer: A Vulcanian eruption is a type of volcanic eruption characterized by short, violent, cannon-like explosions that produce dense, dark ash clouds, ballistic blocks and bombs, and moderate ash columns. The eruption type was defined based on detailed scientific observations of Vulcano's 1888–1890 eruption by Italian geologists Mercalli and Silvestri. Vulcanian eruptions typically involve relatively viscous magma that forms a plug in the conduit, which is then explosively fragmented when gas pressure exceeds the plug's strength. This eruption type is common at intermediate-composition stratovolcanoes worldwide.

faqs.question: What happened at Vulcano in 2021?
faqs.answer: In September 2021, INGV detected a significant increase in volcanic gas emissions (particularly CO2 and SO2), ground temperatures, and micro-seismicity at Vulcano. Italian authorities raised the alert level from green to yellow, and briefly to orange. Gas concentrations at Porto di Levante near the volcanic mud baths reached levels concerning for human health, and access to the summit crater area was restricted. The unrest lasted several months before gradually subsiding, though elevated gas emissions persisted into 2022. No eruption occurred, but the episode demonstrated that Vulcano remains capable of renewed activity.

faqs.question: How do you get to Vulcano?
faqs.answer: Vulcano is reached by hydrofoil or ferry from Milazzo on Sicily's northern coast (1–1.5 hours). Frequent connections also run from Lipari (10 minutes), Stromboli, and other Aeolian islands. In summer, services are frequent; in winter, connections are reduced and may be cancelled in poor weather. Milazzo is accessible by train from Palermo, Catania, or Messina. Once on Vulcano, the island is small enough to explore on foot, though local buses and rental scooters are available.

faqs.question: Are the Vulcano mud baths safe?
faqs.answer: The volcanic mud baths (Fanghi) at Porto di Levante are generally considered safe for short immersions during normal volcanic conditions, though they are not officially supervised. The water temperature is warm (not scalding), and the sulfurous mud is popularly believed to have therapeutic properties for skin conditions and joint pain. However, hydrogen sulfide (H2S) gas can be present, and people with respiratory conditions or heart problems should exercise caution. During the 2021 volcanic unrest, gas concentrations at the mud baths reached concerning levels and access was restricted. Pregnant women, children, and those with health conditions should consult medical advice before bathing.

faqs.question: What is the difference between Vulcano and Stromboli?
faqs.answer: Both are volcanoes in Italy's Aeolian Islands, but they differ significantly. Stromboli is famous for its near-continuous eruptions — it has been erupting almost without pause for over 2,000 years, producing small explosions every few minutes. Vulcano last erupted in 1888–1890 and is currently in a fumarolic (degassing) state. Stromboli (924 m) is taller than Vulcano (500 m). Vulcano is historically significant as the volcano that named all others and defined the 'Vulcanian' eruption type, while Stromboli gave its name to the milder 'Strombolian' eruption type. Both are popular tourist destinations and are connected by frequent hydrofoil services.

schema_data.name: Vulcano
schema_data.description: The volcano that named all others — dormant stratovolcano in Italy's Aeolian Islands with active fumaroles and 44 Holocene eruptions
